title: For my book, set in the Victorian era in England, the main character  is Norwegian. What name might she have with a meaning such as warrior, or protector, or another really pretty name? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, not sure how pretty it is to English speakers, but Borghild is a classic Norwegian girl name meaning “Protection in battle”. (The first part is related to Scottish word burgh, originally meaning castle, and the Norwegian word “berge”, to save or rescue.) So that seems to be the closest, and would be quite plausible for a Norwegian woman in that era. It is often pronounced with a distinct h like in the beginning of words, as if it was written “borg-hild”, but it is written as one word. This is generally the name with two-part names from Scandinavia. Any name starting or ending in “hild” has to do with battle and fighting, and they are disturbingly common among Norwegian women throughout the ages. I guess Norwegian girls were never famous for their meekness… Magnhild - “Strength in battle”. Audhild: “Destiny in battle” or, more disturbing, “Prosperity in battle”. Perhaps a bit too Viking, the second part, but fairly easy to pronounce. Gunnhild: “Battle, battle”. Perhaps a bit too on the nose? Especially with the probably coincidental similarity to the English word “gun”… Another easy to say name. Torhild: “Thor’s battle” or “Thunder in battle”. Can be spelled Torill. which may be easier to pronounce? Svanhild: “Swan in battle”. Norse myth and folklore associate swans with the Valkyries. If you’ve intruded on swans near their young you can probably guess why. They intimidate above their weight class and have way too little fear for their own good. Speaking of Valkyries: A common Norwegian girl name is Vigdis, meaning “Battle goddess”. A bit over the top for your use, I guess, but not too hard on the tongue. There are many more Norwegian names, but these were the ones I thought of in your context. All of them are attested from the era your book is set. I’ve omitted names with Nordic special letters like ø and å, since this is clearly going to be a book for an international audience. Best of luck with your book!

Easy answer from Wikipedia- Valkyrie names[edit] Name Name meaning Referred to as a valkyrie in Brynhildr "Armor battle" or "bright battle"[6] Skáldskaparmál Eir "Peace, clemency" [7] or "help, mercy"[8] Nafnaþulur Geirahöð Connected to the Old Norse words geirr ("spear") and höð ("battle"). [9] Appears in some manuscripts of Grímnismál in place of the valkyrie name Geirölul [9] Geiravör "Spear-vör"[9] Nafnaþulur Geirdriful "Spear-flinger"[9] Nafnaþulur Geirönul, Geirrönul, Geirömul, Geirölul (various spellings) Uncertain; possibly connected to the Odinic name Geirölnir and the dwarf name Ölnir. [10] Possibly meaning "the one charging forth with the spear".[10] The form Geirölul may be connected to the runic charm word alu. [10] Grímnismál, Nafnaþulur Geirskögul "Spear-skögul" [11] (see Skögul entry below) Hákonarmál, Völuspá, Nafnaþulur Göll "Tumult" [12] or "noise, battle"[13] Grímnismál, Nafnaþulur Göndul "Wand-wielder"[12] Völuspá, Nafnaþulur Guðr or Gunnr "War"[12] or "battle"[14] Völuspá, Darraðarljóð, Gylfaginning, Nafnaþulur Herfjötur "Host-fetter" [12] or "fetter of the army" [4]Grímnismál, Nafnaþulur Herja Related to the Old Norse herja and Old High German herjón (meaning "devastate")[15]Nafnaþulur Hlaðguðr svanhvít "Hlaðguðr swan-white"[16] Völundarkviða Hildr "Battle" [17] Völuspá, Grímnismál, Darraðarljóð, Nafnaþulur Hjalmþrimul Possibly "Helmet clatterer" or "female warrior" [18] Nafnaþulur Hervör alvitr Alvitr possibly means "all-wise" or "strange creature" [19] Völundarkviða Hjörþrimul "The sword warrioress," derived from Old Norse hjörr ("sword") and þrima ("battle, noise") [18] Darraðarljóð, Nafnaþulur Hlökk "Noise, battle"[12]Grímnismál, Nafnaþulur Hrist Related to Old Norse hrista (meaning "shake, quake") and therefore meaning "the quaking one"[20] Grímnismál, Nafnaþulur Hrund "Pricker" [12] Nafnaþulur Kára Either "the wild, stormy one" (based on Old Norse afkárr, meaning "wild") or "curl" or "the curly one" [21] Helgakviða Hundingsbana II Mist "Cloud" or "Mist" [22] Grímnismál, Nafnaþulur Ölrún Possibly "ale-rune" [23] Völundarkviða Randgríðr, Randgrid "Shield-truce" [12] or possibly "shield-destroyer" [24]Grímnismál, Nafnaþulur Ráðgríðr "Council-truce" [12] or possibly "the bossy"[25] Grímnismál, Nafnaþulur Reginleif "Power-trace” [12] or "daughter of the gods"[26] Grímnismál, Nafnaþulur Róta Possibly connected to the Old Norse noun róta (meaning "sleet and storm")[27] Gylfaginning Sanngriðr "Very violent, very cruel" [28] Darraðarljóð Sigrdrífa "Victory-urger"[12] or "inciter to victory" [29] Sigrdrífumál Sigrún "Victory rune" [12] Helgakviða Hundingsbana I, Helgakviða Hundingsbana II Skalmöld "Sword-time" [30] Nafnaþulur Skeggöld or Skeggjöld "Axe-age" [12] Grímnismál, Nafnaþulur Skögul "Shaker" [12] or possibly "high-towering" [1] Hákonarmál, Völuspá, Grímnismál, Nafnaþulur Skuld Possibly "debt" or "future" [31] Völuspá, Gylfaginning, Nafnaþulur Sveið Unclear; possibly "vibration" or "noise" [32] Nafnaþulur Svipul "Changeable" [5] Darraðarljóð, Nafnaþulur Þögn "Silence" [33] Nafnaþulur Þrima "Fight" [34] Nafnaþulur An Icelandic-English Dictionary. Clarendon Press.Hard Answer- These are the best lists of Norwegian based female names I could find.

What a fun project for you, Jahmeelah Rose! Some good suggestions have been made here already. If your novel had been set somewhat earlier than the Victorian era, perhaps as early as the time of the Danelaw, the Norwegian names might have had more of an Icelandic/Old Norse ring to them. I like these names for their slightly antique sounds, (but of course the choice of your character names is entirely up to you): Borghilda — “Castle-fighter”;Fridgunn — “Protecting Valkyrie”;Frøydis — “Lady seer”;Synnøva — “Sunlight-giver”;Svanfrida — “Swanlike beauty”;Velena — “I will protect”;Vigdis — “Warrior-woman”;Vigjærd — “Home-protector”.Whatever names you pick, I hope you are able to achieve a great historical novel, and I wish you well.

Mathilde (strong in battle) Hedda (strong in war) Live (lee-va) (protection) Karoline (warrior/soldier) Tófa (Beautiful Thunder) Birgit or Birgitta (Powerful/Strong) Solvi (House of Strength) Pretty Names: Linnea Maja Asta Inger Ingunn Vibeka Lillian Ragnhild (pronunciation is tricky, the English who always anglicize foreign names would probably call her Ronald as there is a similar old English feminine name with similar pronunciation.) Synnøve Reidun Solveig (Very pretty properly pronounced, but consider the anglicization of names. ‘sol-VIGH’ vs anglicized: ’SOLV-ig’) Well that’s some research you don’t have to do. tick tick ;) ~BH

You can can name your the novel Beskytte Kriger – Norwegian for Protecting Warrior. It is an exotic name - and you can even give even the title of the book too - that surely will attract attention and so you can blend your character with the setting and the action.
